conclusion: Objects A and B start moving simultaneously from the same location at rest.
The vertical axis shows acceleration and the horizontal axis shows time.
Object A has constant acceleration represented by a horizontal line.
Object B has linearly increasing acceleration represented by a diagonal line from the origin.
Object A has constant acceleration a₀ from t=0 to t=t₁.
Object B has linearly increasing acceleration starting at 0 and increasing with time.
Express acceleration functions: a_A(t) = a₀ and a_B(t) = kt.
Integrate acceleration to find velocity for Object A: v_A(t₁) = a₀·t₁.
Integrate acceleration to find velocity for Object B: v_B(t₁) = k·t₁²/2.
Determine constant k using the graph: k·t₁ = a₀, thus k = a₀/t₁.
Substitute k to find v_B(t₁): v_B(t₁) = a₀·t₁/2.
Compare velocities at t₁: v_A(t₁) = a₀·t₁ and v_B(t₁) = a₀·t₁/2.
Final answer: No, the two objects do not have the same velocity at time t₁.
